title: Hyperolius igbettensis
text:
Hyperolius igbettensis is a species of <a href="frog">frog</a> in the family <a href="Hyperoliidae">Hyperoliidae</a>. It is found in <a href="West%20Africa">West Africa</a> from <a href="Guinea">Guinea</a> eastward to <a href="Liberia">Liberia</a>, <a href="Ivory%20Coast">Ivory Coast</a>, <a href="Ghana">Ghana</a>, <a href="Togo">Togo</a> and <a href="Benin">Benin</a> (confirmed records from these two countries are lacking), <a href="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>, and into <a href="Central%20Africa">Central Africa</a> at least to <a href="Cameroon">Cameroon</a> but likely further east to the <a href="Central%20African%20Republic">Central African Republic</a> and southwestern <a href="Chad">Chad</a>; the eastern border of distribution of this species relative to other members in the "<a href="Hyperolius%20nasutus">Hyperolius nasutus</a>" complex is unclear. Common name Igbetti long reed frog has been coined for it (spelling "Igebetti" is also used). The <a href="Type%20locality%20%28biology%29">type locality</a> is near Igbetti, a village in <a href="Oyo%20State">Oyo State</a>, Nigeria.
Description.
Males from Nigeria measure and females in snout–vent length; materials from Cameroon indicate a maximum length of for both sexes. The body is long and slender. The fingers and toes are webbed and bear discs; the toe are more webbed but bear smaller discs than the fingers. Colouration is variable, ranging from a light bluish green to grass green or almost green-brown. The shanks and the arms are almost transparent blue-green. The flanks, back and thighs are darker green and bear many small dark spots that may be arranged along vertebral line into a broken line. The head might be darker (reddish brown) than rest of the upper surfaces. Some specimens, primarily males, have a light white to yellow dorsolateral stripe. The <a href="Canthus%20%28herpetology%29">canthal</a> stripe is dark. The <a href="Iris%20%28anatomy%29">iris</a> is reddish and bordered by narrow blue line. The ventral surfaces are light and the belly is whitish, often almost transparent. In females, the eggs are visible through the body wall.
The <a href="Sexual%20selection%20in%20amphibians%23Vocal%20signaling%20in%20frogs">male advertisement call</a> consists of an initial brief note with 12 pulses, and is followed by five
slower pulses, with a duration of 0.12 seconds.
Habitat and conservation.
"Hyperolius igbettensis" occurs in <a href="savanna">savanna</a>s and grassy habitats, but not in drier areas. Breeding takes place near pools, grassy flooded areas, and ditches. The males call from grasses above water.
"Hyperolius igbettensis" is probably a common species. Threats to it are poorly known, but it is unlikely to face significant threats. It probably occurs in several protected areas.
